text:
CHRISTINE LIU: My life right
now is just video meetings.

You have this pressure
to be camera-ready.

You're on the screen for
meetings all day at work.
[SITCOM MUSIC]

And then even afterwards
you got to look presentable
for your friend call.

[SITCOM MUSIC] Or be alert
for your family call.
[SITCOM MUSIC]

Actually there's
intense pressure

to be camera-ready back
when this all felt new,

I actually pointed
the camera at myself
and recorded a time capsule.

Some predictions I
had were not correct.

So the latest we
have, officially,

is that the office will
be closed for four weeks.

But my best estimate
is that it probably
will be closer to two months.

Not long after I filmed
that time capsule,

we started production on
the very first episode
of Christine Versus Work.

That was when we were
shooting this on my phone,
and the wifi is--
I don't know.

Everything looks
really-- I look weird.
My hair's so short.

And in that episode, I
talked to Rachel Cossar.

She's a former Boston
Ballet dancer turned
professional presence coach.

And I'm like, well,
what are the tips?

How am I supposed to carry
myself on these video calls?

RACHEL COSSAR: We don't have
to be stoic non-moving robots.
It just-- it's not interesting.

CHRISTINE LIU: Here we are a
year later and I'm wondering,

does virtual presence
still matter?
Probably, yes.

But as we've been in
video calls and meetings

and been fatigued
all this time, it's

like, I think my standards have
been slipping a little bit.
[SLURPING]

We are all video stars
in our meetings, now.

Question is, how do we make
the most of our on-screen time?

I decided to check
back in with Rachel.

Let's see what she has
to say one year later.

RACHEL COSSAR: You
know, the wildest thing

is that we were all collectively
thrown into this virtual world
simultaneously.

As we found, right,
there's this skills gap,

and that's both the
technology awareness

of the platforms we're
using and then also what
we can do with our physicality.

CHRISTINE LIU: Why does
virtual presence still
really matter a year into this?

RACHEL COSSAR: When
everything aligns

to send an impression of
confidence and professionalism,

it also sets you up to be more
energized, more focused, more
articulate.

Conversely, if they're
off they really

do detract from your
audience's impression of you
from the get go.
CHRISTINE LIU: Fine.
I get it.
We shouldn't slouch and slurp.

We should care about
virtual presence.
Got it.

What has changed since
last March and what hasn't?

RACHEL COSSAR: The thing
that's most amazing

to me in the
segment that we did,

I think it was like a week
into the stay at home order

here in the US, a lot of what
we said was very much on point.

CHRISTINE LIU: We were
actually right a year ago.
So here's a quick recap.

You want to show
your physicality.

So that means being
about three feet away

from the camera
so people can see
most of you and your gestures.

You want to come across
as human, not a robot.

[JARRING ELECTRONIC NOISE]
If you

want to be fully engaged
in a meeting, be on camera
but turn your selfie view off.
I love this tip.

This way you're not kind of
distracted the whole time,
sort of glancing at yourself.

And instead, you're
fully focused
on everyone else in the call.

Lastly, if you have a few
moments before your call,

do some physical
anchoring exercises
to refresh your body and mind.

RACHEL COSSAR: And reach up
to the sky with your hands.
Open them to the side.

How wide and how much
space can you take up?

And now we're going to do tiny
little circles with our palms.

CHRISTINE LIU: Now that we
have the physicality down time
for the technology.

OK, these might
seem super obvious,
but let's go through them.

Consider this a virtual
presence check up for you.
And also for me.
Lay it on me, Rachel.
So, Rachel, be honest.

What do you think of
my setup on this call?

RACHEL COSSAR: So, I think
your setup is decent.

I think there are
a couple of things.

CHRISTINE LIU: [LAUGHTER]
Yes let's do it.
Let's do it.

RACHEL COSSAR: A
couple of things.

Right now we're getting a
little bit more negative space

than we need between
the top of your head

and the outer limit
of that screen.

You see less of me, and you
see less of my gestures.
CHRISTINE LIU: OK.
Yes.

RACHEL COSSAR: By
adjusting that--
right.
So now I see more of Christine.

And then the other thing is
that because you have a window,

we're getting an
orb-like presence

in your frame, which means
that the sharpness of you
is minimized.

CHRISTINE LIU: OK,
so, I have that.

And then let me see if I
can get the ring light.
This is real, folks.
I didn't expect this.
So in that clip.

I'm running out
to go grab my ring
light from across the room.

And then Rachel has a huge
one, which I super love.

But you can also
use natural light,
which is what I have here.

I'm not using a
ring light right now
and you can see me just fine.

RACHEL COSSAR: From a
lighting perspective,
it's much improved.

It's easier for me
to see your humanity.
CHRISTINE LIU: Is it working?
[MUSIC] It's a new beginning.

CHRISTINE LIU: I
know that there are

big fans of virtual
backgrounds out there,

but Rachel recommends
against them and going real.

RACHEL COSSAR: If the goal
is to connect human to human,

let's be real and let's not
add these layers of complexity

that really, they just
add more distraction.

CHRISTINE LIU: With
that advice, if you

need to use a virtual
background for whatever reason,

make sure you're in front of
a plain flat solid background.

OK, let's talk about those
times when you really

need to be off camera
during a meeting.

I typically go into
meetings with my camera on

and I like to see
everybody, but once

in a while life is happening
and for whatever reason,

I just don't really
want my camera on.
But I'm still engaged.

What do I do if
someone calls me out
on it or they joke about it?

It's like, I don't
want to deal with this.
How do you address that?

RACHEL COSSAR: I would
just pop into the chat.

Like, hey everyone,
it's great to be here.

I just wanted to let you
know for this meeting I'm
going to keep my camera off.

And it immediately makes
the implicit explicit.
Right?
So name it and claim it.

No one's going to be wondering,
oh is Christine in the car
right now?

Did she go somewhere
else and she's
with a different background?
No one.
It's a waste of everyone's time.

CHRISTINE LIU: OK,
let's recap the set up.
Here's your checklist.
There we go.
Put my jiggies away.
Just for height, OK.
Let's try that out.
Here's my expression.
I can see.
Work with what you got.
Optimize it.

I think this looks
much better, right?
Man, I really miss the office.

And seeing that time capsule
from a year ago, woof!

That brought a lot of
feelings back, you know?

So I was one of the last
people in the office.

I cleaned up everything,
made sure nothing

was going to be
infested with raccoons
by the time we got back.

Leaving the office was
like packing up for a trip
to the moon.

Sometimes I do
feel like I'm alone

on the moon in my
space in my apartment.

But, hey, those
guys on the moon,
they had to figure it out.
ASTRONAUT 1: Voice check please.

ASTRONAUT 2: We'd like it to
come left about five degrees.
Over.

ASTRONAUT 1: Oh,
jeez, that's great.
Is the lighting halfway decent?
ASTRONAUT 2: Yes, indeed.
ASTRONAUT 1: Beautiful.
Just beautiful.

CHRISTINE LIU: If you're still
watching, one, thank you.
But two, I'm really curious.

Like, what do you
want me to explore?

Like what problems
do you have at work?
I'd love to solve them.
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right.
Peace out.
